<!-- Thanks for taking the time to report this build failure. To proceed with the report please:

1. Title the issue "Installation issue: <name-of-the-package>".
2. Provide the information required below.

We encourage you to try, as much as possible, to reduce your problem to the minimal example that still reproduces the issue. That would help us a lot in fixing it quickly and effectively! -->

### Steps to reproduce the issue

<!-- Fill in the exact spec you are trying to build and the relevant part of the error message -->
Reproducible on CentOS 7, as well as (I suspect) any platform where native compiler in `/usr/bin` uses an old ABI.
```console
$ spack install gcc@7.5.0
$ spack compiler add --scope site $(spack location -i gcc@7.5.0)
$ spack install root@6.22.06%gcc@7.5.0
```
Compilation succeeds. However...
```console
$ spack load gcc@7.5.0 root@6.22.06
$ echo '#include "TObject.h"\nstruct Test : public TObject {\nClassDef(Test, 1)\n};' >Test.h
$ rootcling Test_dict.cxx Test.h
Error in <TInterpreter::InspectMembers>: TClass and cling disagree on the size of the class TBaseClass, respectively 152 128

Error in <TInterpreter::InspectMembers>: TClass and cling disagree on the size of the class TClassRef, respectively 40 16

Error in <TInterpreter::InspectMembers>: TClass and cling disagree on the size of the class TClassRef, respectively 40 16
```
The errors indicate an ABI mismatch between the compiler that was used to build ROOT (gcc 7.5.0) and the compiler that was used to inspect the `Test.h` header file. Indeed, running `rootcling` under `strace` shows that `rootcling` seems to invoke the compiler as `cc`. There is no such symlink in the `gcc` Spack installation, so the link is found in `/usr/bin/cc`, which points to `/usr/bin/gcc`. This was really tricky to figure out! I discussed the issue at length with the ROOT developers [here](https://root-forum.cern.ch/t/tclass-and-cling-disagree-on-the-size-of-the-class/44831).

I would argue that this is a Spack bug. First of all, ROOT really depends on the compiler it was used to build it, although I don't know if Spack is capable of expressing (I don't think we can use `depends_on()`) and enforcing this dependence. Second, the build is broken, but subtly so. I would argue that this is much worse than a package that does not compile.

### Information on your system

<!-- Please include the output of `spack debug report` -->
```console
$ spack debug report
* **Spack:** 0.16.1-2700-57017d5
* **Python:** 3.6.8
* **Platform:** linux-centos7-skylake_avx512
* **Concretizer:** original
```

I tested this in an environment with this configuration:
```console
$ cat spack.yaml
spack:
  specs: [gcc@7.5.0%gcc@7.5.0, python@3.9.0, root@6.22.06 ~opengl ~gdml ~xml ~x ^python@3.9.0]
  view: true
  packages:
    all:
      target: [x86_64]
```
The additional build flags for ROOT are simply there to remove some dependencies from the concretized spec and accelerate the build.

### Additional information

<!-- Please upload the following files. They should be present in the stage directory of the failing build. Also upload any config.log or similar file if one exists. -->
* [spack-build-out.txt](https://github.com/spack/spack/files/6539104/spack-build-out.txt)
* [spack-build-env.txt](https://github.com/spack/spack/files/6539105/spack-build-env.txt)

<!-- Some packages have maintainers who have volunteered to debug build failures. Run `spack maintainers <name-of-the-package>` and @mention them here if they exist. -->

@HadrienG2 @chissg @drbenmorgan @vvolkl 

### General information

<!-- These boxes can be checked by replacing [ ] with [x] or by clicking them after submitting the issue. -->
- [x] I have run `spack debug report` and reported the version of Spack/Python/Platform
- [x] I have run `spack maintainers <name-of-the-package>` and @mentioned any maintainers
- [x] I have uploaded the build log and environment files
- [x] I have searched the issues of this repo and believe this is not a duplicate
title: Installation issue: root
